The company has adopted an Anti-Insider Trading Policy governing the purchase, sale and/or other dispositions of our securities by our directors, officers, employees and contractors . The policy is reasonably designed to promote compliance with insider trading laws, rules and regulations and applicable listing standards . A copy of our Anti-insider trading Policy is filed with this Annual Report as Exhibit 19.1 .

 The following materials are from American Tower Corporation’s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2020, formatted in XBRL (Extensible Business Reporting Language) The confidential portions of the exhibit have been omitted and are marked by an asterisk . The exhibit has been filed separately with the Commission pursuant to an application for confidential treatment . The report was signed on its behalf by the undersigned on the 25th day of February, 2025 .
 This report has been duly signed below by the following persons on behalf of the Registrant and in the capacities and on the dates indicated . The Registrant is a registered Registered Public Accounting Firm with American Tower Tower Tower and Subsidiaries . The registrant is an independent registered public accounting firm with American Towers Towers and its subsidiaries .
 The financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America . We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) (U.S. CAOB)
 The Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013) issued a report dated February 25, 2025, expressed an unqualified opinion on the company's internal control over financial reporting . The report says that the committee's responsibility is to assess whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement, whether due to error or fraud .
 The communication of critical audit matters does not alter in any way our opinion on the financial statements . The estimated useful life of the tower assets should be changed from 20 years to 30 years . The change in useful life resulted in (i) a $515 million increase to the right of use assets and related lease liabilities as of January 1, 2024 .
 There was a high degree of auditor judgment in evaluating  management’s assumptions and estimates and required the assistance of valuation specialists to validate the appropriateness of assumptions made by management . The audit procedures related to the change in estimated useful life of tower assets included the following: inquiry of management and operations and engineering personnel to understand the process to build, inspect, and maintain tower assets .
 The American Tower Tower Corporation and Subsidiaries have served as the Company’s auditor since 1997 . Deloitte & Touche LLP has reviewed the Company's financial records . The Company's current and long-term liabilities include liabilities of discontinued operations.  and operating lease liabilities. The Company has no current assets of $1,999.6.6 .

 The American Tower Tower Corporation and its subsidiary corporate financial activities generated cash and operating expenses from operating activactivities . The Company's net income is $2,280.2 per year; the company's net balance is $9,648.7 per year . The company's operating expenses are $1,696.1 per year, the company paid $4.8 per year. The Company paid $478,388.4 per year for the Company's operations .
 Cash and cash equivalents increased from $1,590.0 billion to $3,696.2 billion . Cash used for investing activities includes cash from short-term borrowings, net interest from ATC TIPL, and cash from non-current assets . Cash and restricted cash decreased from $2,000 to $1.1 billion in cash and equivalents .
 American Tower Corporation (together with its subsidiaries, “ATC” or the “Company”) is one of the largest global real estate investment trusts . The Company’s primary business is the leasing of space on communications sites to wireless service providers, radio and television broadcast companies, wireless data providers, government agencies and municipalities .
 American Tower Corporation is a holding company that conducts its operations through its directly and indirectly owned subsidiaries and joint ventures . ATC’s principal domestic operating subsidiaries are American Towers LLC and SpectraSite Communications, LLC . The Company also holds other telecommunications infrastructure, fiber and property interests that it leases primarily to communications service providers and third-party tower operators .
 The use of TRSs enables the Company to continue to engage in certain businesses and jurisdictions while complying with REIT qualification requirements . As of December 31, 2024, the Company’s REIT-qualified businesses included its U.S. tower leasing business, a majority of its DAS networks business, its Services and Data Centers segments . Investments in entities that the Company does not control are accounted for using the equity method or as investments in equity securities .
 The Company completed the sale of its subsidiary ATC Telecom Infrastructure Private Limited (“ATC TIPL), which held the Company’s operations in India . The divestiture qualified for presentation as discontinued operations . As of December 31, 2024, ATC Europe holds an  87% and an .-83% controlling interest in subsidiaries that consist of the Company's operations in Germany and Spain (PGGM holds the noncontrolling interest)
 On November 11, 2024, the Company completed the sale of ATC Australia and ATC New Zealand . The Company recorded a gain on the sales of those sales of $8.5.5-million . The change in reportable segments had no impact on the Company’s consolidated financial statements for any periods . As a result of the sale, ATC has six reportable segments: U.S. & Canada property, Africa & APAC property, Europe property, Latin America property, Data Centers and Services .
 The company's financial statements are presented in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States . Actual results may differ from those presented in the accompanying financial statements . The company says it is committed to a plan to dispose of an asset that is not immediately available to the public, and that the plan is likely to be completed .
 The Company classifies the results of operations related to a disposal of assets and liabilities (“the disposal group”) in discontinued operations in the consolidated statements of operations . The Company reassesses the fair value less costs to sell of assets held for sale in each reporting period in that period . Gains (losses) are recorded in Other operating income .
 The results of operations classified as discontinued operations are reported in Loss from discontinued operations, net of taxes in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations for all periods presented . The Company derives the largest portion of its revenues and corresponding accounts receivable and the related deferred rent asset from a relatively small number of customers in the telecommunications industry .
 Accounts receivable is reported net of allowances for doubtful accounts related to estimated losses resulting from a customer’s inability to make required payments . Allowances are generally estimated based on payment patterns, days past due and collection history . Receivables are written-off against the allowances or reserves when they are determined to be uncollectible .
 The Company recorded the following net foreign currency (gains) losses: $660.8-$680.8 Foreign currency losses recorded in Other expense . The Company adopted highly inflationary accounting as of January 1, 2024 for its subsidiary in Ghana . All monetary and non-monetary assets and liabilities were remeasured at the U.S. Dollar to Ghanaian Cedis excha .
 The Company adopted highly inflationary accounting as of October 1, 2024 for its subsidiary in Nigeria . The functional currency of its subsidiary became the U.S. Dollar . Non-monetary assets and liabilities, as well as the corresponding income statement activities such as depreciation, amortization and equity, will continue to be measured at the historical exchange rate on December 31, 2023 .
 Cash and cash equivalents include cash on hand, demand deposits and short-term investments with original maturities of three months or less . Restricted cash includes cash pledged as collateral to secure obligations and all cash whose use is otherwise limited by contractual provisions . Property and equipment is recorded at cost or, in the case of acquired properties, at estimated fair value on the date acquired .
 The Company previously depreciated its towers on a straight-line basis over the shorter of the term of the underlying ground lease (including renewal options) taking into account residual value or the estimated useful life of the tower . On January 1, 2024, the Company began depreciating its towers . The Company accounted for the changes in the useful lives as a change in accounting estimate under ASC 250Accounting Changes and Error Corrections .
 The extension of the asset lives (i) resulted in an approximately $515.515-million increase in the right of use asset, as additional renewal options may be included, with an offsetting adjustment made to increase the related operating lease liability . The Company records impairment charges, which are discussed in note 16, in Other operating expenses in the consolidated statements of operations .
 During the year ended December 31, 2023, the Company concluded that a triggering event occurred with respect to its India reporting unit . The result of the Company’s goodwill impairment test indicated that the carrying amount of the company's India unit exceeded its estimated fair value . The Company recorded a goodwill impairment charge of $322.0 million during the quarter ended September 30, 20 23 .
 The carrying amount of the Company’s Spain reporting unit exceeded its estimated fair value . As a result, the Company recorded a goodwill impairment charge of $80.0 million . Impairments primarily result from a site not having current tenant leases or from having expenses in excess of revenues . The Company monitors its tenant-related intangible assets on a tenant by tenant basis for indicators of impairment .
 If the Company determines that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable, the Company measures any impairment loss based on the projected future discounted cash flows to be provided from the asset or available market information relative to the asset’s fair value . The Company records impairment charges, which are discussed in note 16, in Other operating expenses .
 The Company finalized its review of the estimated settlement dates for its asset retirement obligations during the first quarter of 2024 . The significant assumptions used in estimating the Company’s aggregate asset retirement obligation are: timing of asset removals; cost of asset removal; timing and number of site lease renewals; expected inflation rates; and credit-adjusted, risk-free interest rates .
 The Company remains obligated to pay U.S. federal income taxes on certain earnings and continues to be subject to taxation in its foreign jurisdictions . The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities as a result of a change in tax rates is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date . Management assesses the available positive and negative evidence to estimate if sufficient future taxable income will be generated .
 The Company reports penalties and tax-related interest expense and interest income from tax refunds as a component of the income tax provision in the consolidated statements of operations . Other comprehensive income (loss) refers to items excluded from net income that are recorded as an adjustment to equity, net of tax . As a REIT, the Company must annually distribute to its stockholders an amount equal to 90% of its REIT taxable income .
 The Company applies the acquisition method of accounting where assets acquired and liabilities assumed are recorded at fair value at the date of each acquisition . Any excess of the purchase price paid by the Company over the amounts recognized for assets acquired is recorded as goodwill . The Company continues to evaluate acquisitions for a period not to exceed one year after each transaction to determine whether any additional adjustments are needed .
 The Company’s revenue is derived from leasing the right to use its communications sites, the land on which the sites are located and the land underlying its customers’ sites and the space in its data center facilities . The Company must estimate the timing and amount of future cash flows, including rate and terms of renewal and attrition, and apply the applicable discount rate .
 Total property straight-line revenues for the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023, 2022 and 2022 were $277.6%-6% million, $465.4% and $508.5% respectively . Non-lease property revenue consists primarily of revenue generated from DAS networks, fiber and other property related revenue .
 Some of the Company’s contracts with customers contain multiple performance obligations . For these arrangements, the Company allocates revenue to each performance obligation based on its relative standalone selling price . Revenue is recognized at the point in time the services are completed . The Company has excluded sales tax, value added tax and similar taxes from non-lease revenue .
 The American Tower Tower Corporation provides an overview of the Company's financial results . The Company provides a comprehensive comprehensive comprehensive financial statement statement . The company provides a summary of the company's financial statements . The financial statement includes non-tax revenue, property, services and other non-current assets. The Company also provides an analysis of the financial results of its data centers operations.
 The Company recorded an immaterial change in unbilled receivables attributable to revenue recognized during each of the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023 . The Company accounts for leases using a right-of-use model, which recognizes that a lessee has a financial obligation to make lease payments to the lessor for the right to use the underlying asset during the lease term .
 The Company reviews its right-of-use assets for impairment whenever events, changes in circumstances or other evidence indicate that the carrying amount of the Company’s assets may not be recoverable . Impairments result from a site not having current tenant leases or from having expenses in excess of revenues . The Company records impairment charges, which are discussed in note 16, in Other operating expenses in the period in which the Company identifies such impairment .
 The Company’s calculation of the lease liability includes the term of the underlying ground lease plus all periods, if any, for which failure to renew the lease imposes an economic penalty to the Company such that renewal appears to be reasonably assured . The straight-line component of ground rent expense for the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2022 was $46.8.8677 million . Development expense consists of costs associated with new business initiatives and project cancellation costs .
 In December 2022, the Company’s Compensation Committee changed the terms of its awards to generally vest over three years . Equity awards typically vest ratably . The fair value of stock options is determined using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model . Fair value of PSUs and RSUs granted in 2024 also include a market condition component .
 The Company periodically becomes involved in various claims and lawsuits that are incidental to its business . The Company recognizes all stock-based compensation expense in Selling, general, administrative and development expense . As of December 31, 2024, the Company has withheld from issuance an aggregate of  3.3-4 million shares related to the vesting of restricted stock units .
 The Company has a 401(k) plan covering nearly all eligible employees who meet certain age and employment requirements . The Company uses the treasury stock method to calculate the effect of its outstanding RSUs, PSUs and stock options . At formation, the Company contributed assets with a value of $14.6-million to the Stonepeak Development Partnership and acquired a minority ownership interest .
 In November 2023, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued guidance which is intended to improve reportable segment disclosure requirements . The adoption of this guidance did not have a material impact on the Company’s financial statements and related disclosures . The updated guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2024, with early adoption permitted . The Company adopted this guidance for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2024 .
 The guidance is effective on a prospective basis, with the option for retrospective application, for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2026 . The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this guidance on its consolidated financial statements and related disclosures . Property and equipment (including assets held under finance leases) consisted of the following: prepaid and other current assets .
 Total depreciation expense for the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2022 was $1.1 billion . Depreciation expense includes amounts related to finance lease assets for  the years . The Company considers an arrangement to be a lease if it conveys the right to control the use of the communications infrastructure or ground space underneath communications infrastructures .
 The Company is a lessor in most of its revenue arrangements, as property revenue is derived from tenant leases of specifically-identified, physically distinct space on or in the Company’s communications real estate assets . The Company structures its leases to include financial penalties if a tenant terminates the lease, which serve to disincentivize tenants from terminating the lease .
 The Company typically has more than one tenant on a site and can often lease a site, either through renewing existing agreements or leasing to new tenants, for periods beyond the existing tenant lease term . Fixed power revenue is recognized each month over the term of the lease . The Company has minimal risk with respect to the residual value of its leased assets .
 The Company generally does not enter into sales-type leases or direct financing leases . If incentives are present in the Company’s leases, they are evaluated to determine proper treatment and, to the extent present, are recorded in Other current assets and Other non-current assets in the consolidated balance sheets . As of December 31, 2024, the remaining weighted average amortization period of the Company's lease incentives wa.
 The Company has entered into certain transactions whereby at the end of a lease, sublease or similar arrangement, the Company has the option to purchase the corresponding communications sites . Ground lease arrangements usually include annual escalations and do not contain any residual value guarantees or restrictions on dividends, other financial obligations or other similar terms . The Company concluded that these incremental renewals were lease modifications and has accounted for them accordingly .
 The Company’s lease liability is the present value of the remaining minimum rental payments to be made over the remaining lease term, including renewal options reasonably certain to be exercised . The Company assesses its right-of-use asset and other lease-related assets for impairment, as described in note 1 . As of December 31, 2024, the Company does not have any material related party leases as a lessee .
 The Company uses a market-specific incremental borrowing rate consistent with the lease term as of the lease commencement date or upon a remeasurement event when calculating the present value of the remaining lease payments . The remaining lease term does not reflect all renewal options available to the Company, only those renewal options that the Company has assessed as reasonably certain of being exercised .
 Interest expense on finance lease liabilities was $1.0.0 million, $.1.1 million and $.2 million for the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2022, respectively . Cash flow information is as follows: Operating cash flows from operating leases (1) and (2) non-cash items: New operating leases and leases acquired in connection with acquisitions .
 The changes in the carrying value of goodwill for each of the Company’s business segments were as follows:    U.S., Canada, Africa & APAC, Latin America and Asia . The Company's goodwill includes goodwill associated with the India reporting unit, which is reported as discontinued operations . See note 22 for further discussion .
 The Company reviews goodwill for impairment annually (as of December 31) or whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable, as further discussed in note 1 . The Company recorded a goodwill impairment charge of $80.0-million associated with the sale of one of our subsidiaries in Mexico that held fiber assets (“Mexico Fiber”), which was sold during the year ended December 31, 2023 .
 As of December 31, 2024, reflects the change in estimated useful lives as described in note 1 . Acquired network location intangibles are amortized over the remaining estimated useful life of the tower, taking into account residual value, generally up to  previously up to 20 years . The acquired tenant-related intagibles typically represent the value to the Company of tenant contracts and relationships in place at the time of an  F-24F-24 transaction, including assumptions regarding estimated renewals .
 The Company amortizes its acquired intangible assets on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives . The Company evaluates each of its acquisitions under the accounting guidance framework to determine whether to treat an acquisition as an asset acquisition or a business combination . The fair value of these net assets acquired are based on management’s estimates and assumptions, as well as other information compiled by management .
 The Company typically acquires communications sites and other communications infrastructure assets from wireless carriers or other tower operators . In the United States, acquisitions may also include data center facilities and related assets . The date of acquisition, and by extension the point at which the Company begins to recognize the results of an acquisition, may depend on, among other things, the receipt of contractual consents .
 Acquisition, disposition and merger related expenses may include finder’s fees, advisory, legal, accounting, valuation and other professional or consulting fees . Integration costs include incremental and non-recurring costs necessary to convert data and systems, retain employees and otherwise enable the Company to operate acquired businesses or assets efficiently . During the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2022, the Company recorded net benefits of $23.4-4-11.9 million related to pre-acquisition contingencies .
 The year ended December 31, 2022 included acquisition and merger related costs associated with the Stonepeak Transaction (as defined in note 15) The estimated aggregate impact of the acquisitions completed in 2024 on the Company’s revenues and gross margin was not material . The Company acquired a total of  55 communications sites, as well as other communications infrastructure assets, in the United States, Canada and France for an aggregate purchase price of $.5 billion .
 During the year ended December 31, 2024, the Company made .88.6.6 million EUR (approximately $.92.8 million) of deferred payments, including post-closing adjustments, associated with the Company’s acquisition of the European and Latin American tower divisions from Telxius Telecom, S.A. in 2021 (the “Telxius Acquisition”) Included in Deferred financing costs and other financing activities .

 The American Tower Tower Tower's senior notes (9) are comprised of $1.5 billion in cash and interest . The company has a history of senior notes . The U.S. Tower Tower Corporation has the most senior notes in the world . The Company has the lowest senior note number at $841.4 billion .  The Company used the proceeds from the ATC TIPL Transaction to repay existing indebtedness under the  grotesquely F-29F-29 transaction . As of December 31, 2024, the Company borrowed an aggregate of $.1.5.1 billion and repaid $.2 billion of revolving indebtedness . The Company repaid all amounts outstanding under its  $.9 billion senior unsecured multicurrency revolving credit facility, as amended and restated on December 8, 2021 .
 As of December 31, 2024, the key terms under the 2021 Multicurrency Credit Facility, the 2021 Credit Facility and the Company’s $1.0.0 billion unsecured term loan, as amended and restated in December 2021, as further amended (the “2021 Term Loan”) were as follows .
 The Company repaid $1.0 billion aggregate principal amount of the Company’s 5.00.00% senior unsecured notes due 2024 .  The net proceeds from this offering were approximately $1,281.3.3%, after deducting commissions and estimated expenses . The Company used the net proceeds to repay existing EUR indebtedness under the 2021 Multicurrency Credit Facility and the 2021 Credit  Credit Facility Facelade . The company completed a registered public offering of $395.7% senior unsecured notes due 2034 (the “apologetic’s.”) and $600.0%. Senior Unsecured Notes due 2030 and $5.400% Senior Notes due 2035 .
 The Company’s outstanding senior notes as of December 31, 2024 have outstanding seniornotes . The principal amount is $1,000.0 billion and $2.950 billion respectively . The Company's senior notes have outstanding debt obligations of $1.9 billion . Facility Facility Facility. The Company has no debt of $3.2 billion and no debt is currently at risk of default .
 The American Tower Tower Corporation provides financial statements to shareholders and affiliates . The Company's financial statements are comprised of approximately $1.1 billion . At the bottom of the page, the Company provides a summary of its consolidated financial statements and operations . The company's operating expenses are estimated at $2.2 billion and $3.9 billion .
 Includes unamortized discounts, premiums and debt issuance costs . Accrued and unpaid interest on USD denominated notes is payable in USD semi-annually in arrears and will be computed from the issue date on the basis of a 360-day year comprised of twelve 30-day months . Interest on EUR denominated . notes is payment in EUR annually in . interest is committed on the basis on the actual number of days in the period for which interest is being calculated and . including the last date on which interest was paid on the notes, beginning on the issure .
 The Company may redeem the notes at any time, in whole or in part, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the notes plus a make-whole premium, together with accrued interest to the redemption date . The notes rank equally in right of payment with all of the Company’s other senior unsecured debt obligations and are structurally subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness of its subsidiaries .
 As of December 31, 2024, the Company was in compliance with each of these covenants . The Company has several securitizations in place . Cash flows generated by the communications sites that secure the securitized debt of the Company are only available for payment of such debt and are not available to pay the Company’s other obligations .
 The effective weighted average life and interest rate of the 2015 Notes was  rewarded at least 8.1.1-year life and 3.029-year interest rate . The outstanding Series 2015-2 Notes are secured by (i)mortgages, deeds of trust and deeds to secure debt on substantially all of the . 2015 Secured Sites’s operating cash flows, (ii) security interest in substantially all . of the personal property and fixtures of the GTP Entities, including GTP Acquisition Partners’ equity interests in its subsidiaries .
 The assets of the Trust consist of a nonrecourse loan broken into components or “componentized” (the “Loan”), which secures each of the 2018 Securities and the 2023 Securities . To satisfy the Risk Retention Rules, the Trust issued, and one of the Company’s affiliates purchased, $26.4.4 . million aggregate principal amount of Secured Tower Revenue Securities, Series 2018-1, Subclass R . and, together with the . 2023 Securitization, the “Trust Securitizations”
 The 2023 Securities correspond to components of the Loan made to the AMT Asset Subs pursuant to the Second Supplement and Amendment dated as of March 13, 2023 (the 2023 Supplement) and the Second Amended and Restated Loan and Security Agreement dated March 29, 2018 (the “Loan Agreement,” which continues to govern the 2018 Securities, and collectively, the “Trust Loan Agreement”).
 The debt service on the Loan will be paid solely from the cash flows generated from the operation of the Trust Sites held by the AMT Asset Subs . American Tower Holding Sub, LLC (the “Guarantor”), whose only material assets are its equity interests, have each guaranteed repayment of the Loan and pledged their equity interests in their respective subsidiary or subsidiaries as security .
 Excess cash flows generated from the operation of such assets are released to the AMT Asset Subs or GTP Acquisition Partners, as applicable, which can then be distributed to, and used by, the Company . If the DSCR were equal to or below  below  1.30-30, the excess cash flow will be deposited into a reserve account (the “Cash Trap Reserve Account”) instead of being released .
 The Loan Agreement and the 2015 Indenture include operating covenants and other restrictions customary for transactions subject to rated securitizations . Additional interest will accrue on the unpaid principal balance of the Series 2015-2 Notes, and such notes will begin to amortize on a monthly basis from excess cash flow . An “amortization period” also commences if, on the anticipated repayment date the component of the Loan corresponding to the applicable subclass of the Trust Securities has not been repaid in full .
 The organizational documents of the AMT Asset Subs and the GTP Entities contain provisions consistent with rating agency securitization criteria for special purpose entities . Failure to comply with the covenants in the Loan Agreement or the 2015 Indenture could prevent the Company from distributing excess cash flow to the Company . The applicable trustee may seek to foreclose upon or otherwise convert the ownership of all or any portion of the Trust Sites .

 American Tower Tower has six reportable segments: U.S. & Canada property, Africa & APAC property, Europe property, Latin America property, Data Centers and Services . The Company's Asia-Pacific (APAC) property segment and Africa property segment were combined into the Africa &APAC property segment . The change had no impact on the Company’s consolidated financial statements .
 As of December 31, 2024, the Company’s property operations consisted of the following: U.S. & Canada property, Asia-Pacific property, Africa property, Europe property, Latin America property, Data Centers and Services . The Data Centers segment offers different types of leased land and related services from, and requires different resources, skill sets and marketing strategies .
 The Services segment is a strategic business unit that offers different services from, and requires different resources, skill sets and marketing strategies than, the property operating segments . Management uses segment gross margin and segment operating profit in evaluating financial performance in each business segment . The accounting policies applied in compiling segment information below are similar to those described in note 1 .
